title: Which email signature is better between 'Best Regards' and 'Thanks and Regards'? - Quora

response.answer_text: As so often, it depends. The ‘signature’ depends on whom you are mailing and for what reason. I’m not sure there is an approved protocol for this. Here’s what I do: If it’s a ‘formal’ mail (as you might have done in a letter in the past) I use yours sincerely of yours faithfully, using usual letter ‘rules’If it’s less formal, I use Regards or Kind RegardsIf it’s to someone who knows me personally I use Cheers or just ChrisOf your two, I prefer Best Regards, but I pretty well always say thanks in the closing text. Thanks: in anticipation of your assistancefor your attention to this matterI have seen ‘warmest’ or ‘kindest’ regards used and I’m ok with both of these although I don’t use them myself. Slightly off topic, but if an email to me says “Dear” Chris, Mr/Dr Atkins (whatever), I always reply in the same way.

If I’m asking someone to do something for me, I will just type ‘thanks’. In fact, I often use that sign-off, kind of as a subtext of ‘thanks for taking the time to read my email’. It’s personalised based on the message - it needs to fit what you want/need to convey in every single case. For example, I’ll sometimes make it ‘many thanks’ if what they’re going to do for me is particularly helpful/important. So, adopting a standard is inadvisable. I say this specifically for email, which is generally less formal than other written communication. A standard sign-off can begin to seem insincere, especially if people realise that you’ve made it part of your auto-signature. I’ve worked with people who do that, and I’m not impressed.
